question: what allows chyme to enter the small intestine
vanilla_rag_result: Chyme enters the small intestine through the pyloric sphincter, which is a valve located at the junction between the stomach and the duodenum (the first part of the small intestine). When the pyloric sphincter opens, it allows the thick semi-liquid mass of partly digested food, known as chyme, to pass from the stomach into the duodenum.
